etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Nicholas Culpeper (1616–1654), physician and astrologer. From post-classical Latin osteocolla from osteo- + ancient Greek κόλλα glue

definitions: A calcareous deposit forming an incrustation on the roots and stems of plants in sandy ground, especially in some parts of Germany.

notes.text: Formerly also called glue-bone stone, from its supposed ability to help the knitting of broken bones.
